awd_titl_txt: QLCI-CG: Atomic, Molecular, and Photonic Instruments on Chip for Quantum Sensing
awd_abstract_narration:
The Quantum Leap Challenge Institutes (QLCI) program is part of the Quantum Leap, one of the research Big Ideas promoted by the National Science Foundation. This award is a QLCI Conceptualization Grant, which supports activities to build capacity among teams planning for the large-scale, interdisciplinary Challenge Institute projects that aim to advance the frontiers of quantum information science and engineering. Research at these Institutes will span the focus areas of quantum computation, quantum communication, quantum simulation, and/or quantum sensing. The Institutes are expected to foster multidisciplinary approaches to specific scientific, technological, and workforce development goals in these fields.
 
This Conceptualization Grant will develop well-formulated plans for a future Challenge Institute proposal along the theme of advancing microelectronics through atomic and photonic quantum sensing and precision metrology techniques.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A Quantum Leap Challenge Institute entitled AMPICQ: Atomic, Molecular and Photonic Instruments on Chip for Quantum sensing was proposed for this Quantum Leap Conceptualization Grant. This institute will
explore a future in which atoms, molecules and photons are inseparably linked to microelectronics and MEMS/NEMS (Micro/Nano-Electro-Mechanical Systems), and broadly used to build quantum instruments in solid environments. In contrast to fabricated materials, atoms are unique--their structure remains constant over space and time independent whatsoever of any human activity.  The Institute was to synthesize research within 4 thrust areas: (1) Hybrid systems comprised of atoms and ions coupled to MEMS devices, (2) Manipulation of photon entanglement in hybrid organic-inorganic
excitonic materials and microcavities, (3) High-throughput proteomic profiling of single cells enabled by quantum measurement in NEMS and (4) Atomic sensors fabricated in noble gas solids.

Two workshops and multiple smaller meetings were proposed to be held by this interdisciplinary team of 15 physicists, chemists and electrical engineers, many of whom are co-located at Georgia Tech, including the PI and two co-PIs.  However due to COVID only smaller team meetings were held.  Our activities augmented numerous industry, national and international laboratory partnerships in addition to fostering and building a nationwide university research community that includes a substantial regional presence in the Southeastern United States. Through them a consistent portfolio of research and education for the planned Institute was conceptualized.
